node.title: Parliament protest: Vehicle towing yet to start, police 'focus on engagement'
node.description: Police in Wellington are not yet towing protester vehicles blocking streets around Parliament, and say they are exercising "careful judgement" about when to start.

node.title: Judge says Palin jurors knew he planned to toss claim before they reached a verdict
node.description: The judge said the jurors told a law clerk it didn't affect the outcome.

node.title: Education Department to forgive $415 million in student debt
node.description: The latest round of loan forgiveness brings the total amount approved by the department to approximately $2 billion for more than 107,000 borrowers.

node.title: 'This is not okay': Fed up nurse defaces anti-vax billboard
node.description: A Whangārei nurse is so annoyed by anti-vaccination billboards in Northland, she wore a disguise and spraypainted over misinformation. Audio

node.title: MIQ rules begin to loosen as border opens and Omicron spreads
node.description: More people are expected to be able to leave MIQ early under a new risk assessment, and some travellers may be able to go into self-isolation before borders open.

node.title: Covid-19: NZ Post boosts staffing in preparation for sustained outbreak
node.description: The postal service says 800 extra staff will ensure critical deliveries can continue as the Omicron outbreak grows.

node.title: European Union ambassador says Russia-Ukraine crisis has unified EU and NATO
node.description: Lambrinidis said he is still hopeful that the tensions can be dealt with via diplomacy.

node.title: Survivor tells Abuse in Care inquiry alcohol 'eased the pain'
node.description: A survivor of abuse at the hands of the Catholic Order of St John of God has told the Royal Commission of Inquiry about his treatment at Marylands School - saying he was "interfered with" as soon as…

node.title: 'It's at tipping point': Residents fear influx of helicopters
node.description: Aotea Great Barrier islanders fear they will go the same way as Waiheke Island with lots of helicopters buzzing their skies.

node.title: Harris to travel to Munich amid threat of Russian invasion of Ukraine
node.description: Harris will be meeting with the Ukrainian president and German chancellor, among other world leaders at the Munich Security Conference.

node.title: CDC may update indoor mask guidance as states loosen restrictions
node.description: The debate over masking in schools continues to simmer.

node.title: Parliament protest: Towing operator says companies ready to remove vehicles
node.description: A towing company owner says it could take 20 trucks working unimpeded for a day or so to clear 400 vehicles blocking the streets around Parliament. Audio

node.title: Video of officers handcuffing Black teen after fight draws criticism
node.description: "I was confused, like, why they saw me as a bad person," the teen said of the police officers who pinned him down while the other boy sat on a couch.

node.title: Tāneatua homicide: Man charged with aggravated robbery and assault
node.description: Police believe the man assaulted a 65-year-old man outside the bakery on Tuhoe Street on Monday afternoon and that he was linked to an earlier assualt of a 57-year-old man who later died.

node.title: Parties pressure government for detail on vaccine mandate exit strategy
node.description: The government is facing pressure from some political partes to give a timeframe for when vaccine mandates will be removed or at the least some detail on an exit strategy.

node.title: DOJ sues Missouri over bill declaring several federal firearm laws invalid
node.description: The complaint alleges that the bill, known as the Second Amendment Preservation Act, is unconstitutional.

node.title: Dozens of close contacts at school after masks not worn correctly
node.description: Wakatipu High School has confirmed one student has tested positive for Covid-19, and it has two other probable cases, with 43 students and four teachers identified as close contacts so far.

node.title: 'Rash ruling': Teachers' exclusion from critical worker scheme slated
node.description: Principals are fuming that schools won't have ready access to rapid antigen tests (RATs) to help keep their doors open during the Omicron outbreak. Audio

node.title: Government security group meets over protests at Parliament
node.description: The government has activated a top level national security group as the protest continues in and around Parliament.

node.title: Seymour meets with protesters: Time for a 'mature de-escalation'
node.description: ACT's leader David Seymour says he has passed a message to convoy leaders that it's time for a dialogue, but the PM says it is irresponsible for MPs to meet with the protesters.

node.title: Picton protest: 'It's now time for them to move'
node.description: A trespass notice has been delivered to protesters at a park in Picton. Marlborough's mayor says a conciliatory approach has been tried, but they now have to go. Audio

node.title: Appeals court overturns conviction of Miami cop who shot at unarmed autistic man
node.description: Jonathan Aledda now awaits a new trial, almost six years after the shooting.

node.title: Migrant arrests along southern border dropped by 14% in January
node.description: While the number represents the second-highest month-to-month drop in migrant apprehensions during the Biden administration, it is an all-time high for January.

node.title: Sir Mark Todd suspended over treatment of horse in video
node.description: The former Olympic equestrian champion has been given an interim suspension by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) after a video on social media appeared to show him hit a horse with a branch.

node.title: Businesses prepared to keep vaccine mandates, workers' union says
node.description: A union representing workers across a range of sectors says even if vaccine mandates ended many businesses would keep them going.

node.title: Officials suspend search for people missing from sunken fishing boat off Canada
node.description: During the 36-hour search, which kicked off after the boat capsized early Tuesday morning, officials rescued three survivors and recovered 10 bodies.

node.title: Experts split on raising age of superannuation
node.description: A recommendation from the OECD to raise the age New Zealanders can get the pension has been ruled out by the government, but the National Party's not so sure.

node.title: NZR finally gets deal with Silver Lake across the line
node.description: Silver Lake will invest $200m in a new commercial entity that will control NZR revenue-generating assets, and offer up to $100m to NZ institutional investors later in 2022.

node.title: FMA's new boss wants focus on making a difference for consumers
node.description: The new head of the Financial Markets Authority plans to use empathy, education, and enforcement to deliver good results for consumers and investors.

node.title: 2 of Ahmaud Arbery's killers repeatedly used racial slurs: FBI witness
node.description: The FBI wasn't able to access Greg McMichael's phone because it was encrypted, the witness said.
